importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication indicates the most recent update on the 2025 postseason, specifically the conclusion of the National League Championship Series and the Dodgers' sweep of the Milwaukee Brewers.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The game and events described occurred during the 2025 postseason, with the final game of the NLCS taking place on October 18, 2025.

keyTakeAways: Shohei Ohtani delivered a historic performance in the National League Championship Series, hitting three home runs and striking out 10 batters in a single game.
Ohtani became the first starting pitcher since 1900 to hit multiple home runs in a postseason game and the first since 1900 to hit a leadoff home run in a playoff game.
This performance marked the first time a starting pitcher had pitched in 13 consecutive days, highlighting the physical and mental endurance demonstrated.
The Los Angeles Dodgers swept the Milwaukee Brewers in four games to win the NLCS, securing their spot in the 2025 World Series.
Ohtani was named the National League Championship Series Most Valuable Player (MVP) for his exceptional performance.
The Dodgers are now the first team to return to the World Series the year after winning it since the Philadelphia Phillies in the late 2000s.
No team has repeated as World Series champions since the New York Yankees' 1998–2000 dynasty, making the Dodgers' potential repeat a major event in MLB history.
The Dodgers have lost only one game in the postseason and have not allowed more than one run per game since a prior loss in the NLDS.

namedEntities.name: Shohei Ohtani
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Japanese professional baseball player, two-way star (pitcher and hitter)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ohtani is the central figure in the article due to his unprecedented performance in the NLCS, including three home runs, 10 strikeouts, and a historic pitching-hitting dual role in a postseason game.

namedEntities.name: Los Angeles Dodgers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professional baseball team in Major League Baseball (MLB)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Dodgers are the team achieving a four-game sweep in the NLCS and advancing to the World Series, marking a significant milestone in their recent postseason success.

namedEntities.name: Milwaukee Brewers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professional baseball team in Major League Baseball (MLB)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Brewers are the opposing team defeated by the Dodgers in the NLCS, culminating in the Dodgers' sweep and advancement to the World Series.

namedEntities.name: Freddie Freeman
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Freeman praised Ohtani’s performance, emphasizing the team effort and highlighting the extraordinary nature of Ohtani’s feat in a major postseason game.

namedEntities.name: Clayton Kershaw
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Dodger pitcher and former MLB Hall of Famer
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Kershaw expressed admiration for Ohtani’s performance and acknowledged the team’s strong playoff form and chemistry.

namedEntities.name: Seattle Mariners

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Mariners are mentioned as the opposing team in the American League Championship Series, indicating the Dodgers will face them or another team in the World Series.

namedEntities.name: Toronto Blue Jays
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professional baseball team in Major League Baseball (MLB)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Blue Jays are referenced as the opposing team in the ALCS against the Mariners, indicating the eventual World Series opponent for the Dodgers.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Roberts is quoted as commenting on the team’s success and their historical significance as the first team to return to the World Series the year after winning it.

namedEntities.name: Sarah Langs
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Langs provided statistical context to Ohtani’s historic performance, confirming records broken in MLB history.

namedEntities.name: TNT Sports
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: TNT Sports broadcast the game and reported on Ohtani’s performance and the record-breaking nature of his achievements.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Shohei Ohtani delivered a legendary performance in the 2025 National League Championship Series, hitting three home runs and striking out 10 batters in a single game while pitching a six-inning shutout—making him the first starting pitcher since 1900 to hit multiple home runs in a postseason game and the first to hit a leadoff home run in a playoff. This historic feat, accomplished after pitching 13 consecutive days, led the Los Angeles Dodgers to a four-game sweep over the Milwaukee Brewers and earned Ohtani the NLCS MVP title. The Dodgers, now set to face the American League champion (either the Seattle Mariners or Toronto Blue Jays) in the 2025 World Series, have not lost a game in the postseason and are the first team to return to the World Series the year after winning it since the Phillies in the late 2000s. The performance has sparked widespread acclaim from teammates and fans, with Ohtani calling it a 'team effort' and expressing pride in representing Japan and Los Angeles.
title: Shohei Ohtani’s legendary night leads Los Angeles Dodgers to another World Series, sweeping Milwaukee in 4 games
